page.title: 05Local traditions in Annan
page.content:
The{Hole in the Hedge}Ceremony
Each year in early July, as part of Annan's{Riding of the Marches Celebrations, the Hole in the Hedge Ceremony is re_enacted. A small boy, between 5 and 10, has to climb through a hole in a hedge, near to a house where tradition states, that centuries before a small boy, looking through a hole in a hedge spotted the English approaching on a raid. He was able to warn the adults nearby and thus save the local people being taken by surprise. For centuries raiding parties from both the English and the Scottish farmers have crossed the border to steal each other's cattle, and this ceremony commemorates this part of the area's{turbulant history.
